Question 9: What is the impact of the characters' actions on the world around them, as described in the novel? Options: A. It has no impact on the world., B. It brings great prosperity and happiness to the world., C. It forces people from lower castes off their land and causes environmental damage, leading to widespread despair and suffering., D. It brings great despair and suffering to the world. Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the significance of the novel's title, "The God of Small Things"? Options: A. It refers to a god who is small in size., B. It refers to a god who is powerful and all-knowing., C. It refers to the idea that small actions can have a big impact, which is a major theme in the novel., D. It has no significance in the novel. Correct Option: C

**Transcript**:
“A few dozen hours can affect the 
outcome of whole lifetimes/ And that when they do, 
those few dozen hours, like the salvaged remains 
of a burned clock… must be resurrected from the ruins 
and examined.” This is the premise of Arundhati Roy’s 
1997 novel "The God of Small Things." Set in a town in Kerala, India called 
Ayemenem, the story revolves around fraternal 
twins Rahel and Estha, who are separated for 23 years 
after the fateful few dozen hours in which their cousin drowns, their 
mother’s illicit affair is revealed, and her lover is murdered. While the book is set at the point of 
Rahel and Estha’s reunion, the narrative takes place mostly in
the past, reconstructing the details around the tragic events that 
led to their separation. Roy’s rich language and masterful 
storytelling earned her the prestigious Booker prize 
for "The God of Small Things." In the novel, she interrogates the culture
of her native India, including its social mores 
and colonial history. One of her focuses is the caste system, a way of classifying people by hereditary 
social class that is thousands of years old. By the mid-20th century, the original four castes associated 
with specific occupations had been divided into 
some 3000 sub-castes. Though the caste system was 
Constitutionally abolished in 1950, it continued to shape 
social life in India, routinely marginalizing people 
of lower castes. In the novel, Rahel and Estha have a 
close relationship with Velutha, a worker in their family’s pickle factory and member of the so-called 
“untouchable” caste. When Velutha and the twins’ mother, Ammu,
embark on an affair, they violate what Roy describes as the 
“love laws” forbidding intimacy between 
different castes. Roy warns that the tragic consequences 
of their relationship “would lurk forever in ordinary things,” 
like “coat hangers,” “the tar on roads,” and “the absence of words.” Roy’s writing makes constant use of these 
ordinary things, bringing lush detail to even the most 
tragic moments. The book opens at the funeral of the 
twins’ half-British cousin Sophie after her drowning. As the family mourns, lilies curl and 
crisp in the hot church. A baby bat crawls up a funeral sari. Tears drip from a chin like 
raindrops from a roof. The novel forays into the past to explore
the characters’ struggles to operate in a world 
where they don’t quite fit, alongside their nation’s 
political turmoil. Ammu struggles not to lash out at her 
beloved children when she feels particularly trapped in her
parents’ small-town home, where neighbors judge and shun her 
for being divorced. Velutha, meanwhile, balances his affair
with Ammu and friendship with the twins not only with his employment

budding communist countermovement to Indira Ghandi’s “Green Revolution.” In the 1960s, the misleadingly named

off their land and caused widespread

are all around them. The river that was bursting with life 
in their childhood greets them “with a ghastly skull’s smile,
with holes where teeth had been, and a limp hand raised 
from a hospital bed.” As Roy probes the depths of human 
experience, she never loses sight of the way her 
characters are shaped by the time and the place where they live. In the world of "The God of Small Things," “Various kinds of despair competed 
for primacy… personal despair could never be 
desperate enough... personal turmoil dropped by at the wayside

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
After a savage seafaring skirmish and eight long days of being 
battered by waves, Väinämöinen— a powerful bard and 
sage as old as the world itself— washed up on the shores 
of distant Pohjola. Unlike his home Kalevala, Pohjola was 
a dark and frozen land, ruled by Louhi, “the gap-tooth 
hag of the North." The cunning witch nursed Väinämöinen 
back to health but demanded a reward for 
returning him home. Not content with mere gold or silver, Louhi wanted what did not yet exist— 
the Sampo. To be forged from “the tips of white-swan
feathers," “the milk of greatest virtue," “a single grain of barley," and 
“the finest wool of lambskins," this artifact was said to be 
an endless font of wealth. But Väinämöinen knew that 
only Seppo Ilmarinen, the Eternal Hammerer who forged 
the sky-dome itself, could craft such an object. So he convinced Louhi to send him 
home and fetch the smith. Though the journey was far from easy, 
the bard finally made it back to Kalevala. But Ilmarinen refused to go to the gloomy 
North— a land of witches and man-eaters. But keeping true to his word, Väinämöinen tricked Ilmarinen 
into climbing a giant tree, before summoning a mighty storm 
to carry the smith all the way to Pohjola. Ilmarinen was well received in the North. Louhi lavished her guest with 
extravagant hospitality and promised him the hand 
of her beautiful daughter— if he could craft what she wished. When she finally asked if Ilmarinen 
was capable of forging the Sampo, the powerful smith declared he could 
indeed accomplish the task. But try as he might to bend 
the forge to his will, its fires only produced other artifacts— beautiful in appearance but 
ill-mannered in nature. An elegant crossbow that 
thirsted for blood and a gleaming plow that ruined cultivated
fields among others. Finally, Ilmarinen summoned the winds 
themselves to work the bellows, and in three days time he 
pulled the Sampo, with its lid of many colors from 
the forge’s flames. On its sides the smith carefully crafted 
a grain mill, a salt mill, and a money mill. Louhi was so delighted with the object’s 
limitless productive power that she ran off to lock her treasure 
inside a mountain. But when Ilmarinen tried to 
claim his prize, the promised maiden refused to marry him,
and the smith had to return home alone. Years passed, and while 
Pohjola prospered, Ilmarinen and Väinämöinen were without 
wives or great wealth. Bitter about this injustice, the bard 
proposed a quest to retrieve the Sampo, and the two sailed north with the 
help of Lemminkäinen— a beautiful young man with a history 
of starting trouble. Upon arrival, Väinämöinen requested half 
the Sampo’s profits as compensation— or they’d take the artifact by force. Outraged at this request, Louhi summoned 
her forces to fight the heroes. But as her army readied for war, 
the bard played his magic harp, Kantele, entrancing all who heard it and sending 
Pohjola into a deep slumber. Unimpeded, the three men took the Sampo 
and quietly made their escape. Lemminkäinen was ecstatic 
at their success, and demanded that Väinämöinen sing 
of their triumph. The bard refused, knowing the dangers 
of celebrating too early. But after three days of traveling, 
Lemminkäinen’s excitement overwhelmed him, and he recklessly broke out in song. His awful singing voice woke 
a nearby crane, whose screeching cries roused 
the Pohjolan horde. The army made chase. As their warship closed in, Väinämöinen 
raised a rock to breach their hull. Undeterred, Louhi transformed 
into a giant eagle, carrying her army on her back as they 
attacked the heroes’ vessel. She managed to grab the Sampo 
in her claw, but just as quickly, it dropped into 
the sea, shattering into pieces and sinking deep beyond her talon’s reach. Buried on the ocean floor, the remnants of this powerful device 
remain in the realm of Ahti, god of water— where they grind salt for the seas 
to this very day.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Väinämöinen’s home is located in
Options: A. Pohjola, B. Kalevala, C. The North
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: **Knowledge** Options: A. Väinämöinen is a powerful bard and sage from Kalevala., B. Väinämöinen is a cunning witch from Pohjola., C. Väinämöinen is a young man with a history of starting trouble., D. Väinämöinen is a powerful smith from Kalevala. Correct Option: A
Question 2: **Comprehension** Options: A. Väinämöinen washes up on the shores of Kalevala after a seafaring skirmish., B. Väinämöinen is nursed back to health by Louhi, the gap-tooth hag of the North., C. Väinämöinen is tricked into climbing a giant tree by Louhi., D. Väinämöinen convinces Louhi to send him home to fetch Seppo Ilmarinen. Correct Option: B
Question 3: **Application** Options: A. If you were Väinämöinen, how would you convince Louhi to send you home to fetch Seppo Ilmarinen?, B. What would you do if you were Seppo Ilmarinen and Louhi asked you to craft the Sampo?, C. If you were Lemminkäinen, how would you react to Väinämöinen's refusal to sing of their triumph?, D. What would you do if you were Louhi and Väinämöinen requested half the Sampo's profits as compensation? Correct Option: B
Question 4: **Analysis** Options: A. What are the main reasons why Seppo Ilmarinen refused to go to the North to craft the Sampo?, B. How does Louhi's character change throughout the story?, C. What are the consequences of Lemminkäinen's reckless singing in the story?, D. What is the significance of the Sampo in the story? Correct Option: A
Question 5: **Synthesis** Options: A. Imagine a new character who is a skilled fisherman and has a magical fishing rod. How would this character help Väinämöinen and Lemminkäinen in their quest to retrieve the Sampo?, B. If you were to write a sequel to the story, what would be the main plot points and how would the characters change?, C. What would happen if Väinämöinen and Lemminkäinen were to return to the North and try to retrieve the Sampo again?, D. How would the story change if Louhi were a kind and benevolent character instead of a cunning witch? Correct Option: A
Question 6: **Evaluation** Options: A. Do you think Väinämöinen's decision to refuse to sing of their triumph was justified? Why or why not?, B. Is Louhi a likable character in the story? Why or why not?, C. Do you think the Sampo is an important plot device in the story? Why or why not?, D. Is Lemminkäinen a well-developed character in the story? Why or why not? Correct Option: A
Question 7: **Knowledge** Options: A. Seppo Ilmarinen is the smith who forges the Sampo., B. Louhi is the one who demands the Sampo from Väinämöinen., C. Lemminkäinen is the one who helps Väinämöinen in his quest to retrieve the Sampo., D. Väinämöinen is the one who refuses to go to the North to craft the Sampo. Correct Option: A
Question 8: **Comprehension** Options: A. Väinämöinen and Lemminkäinen sail north with the help of the wind., B. Väinämöinen and Lemminkäinen sail north with the help of a magical boat., C. Väinämöinen and Lemminkäinen sail north with the help of a beautiful maiden., D. Väinämöinen and Lemminkäinen sail north with the help of Lemminkäinen's magical harp. Correct Option: A
Question 9: **Application** Options: A. If you were Väinämöinen, how would you react to Louhi's demand for the Sampo?, B. What would you do if you were Louhi and Väinämöinen refused to give you the Sampo?, C. If you were Lemminkäinen, how would you feel if Väinämöinen refused to sing of their triumph?, D. What would you do if you were Seppo Ilmarinen and Louhi asked you to craft the Sampo? Correct Option: A
Question 10: **Analysis** Options: A. What are the main themes of the story?, B. How does the story relate to the concept of good vs. evil?, C. What are the consequences of Väinämöinen's decision to refuse to sing of their triumph?, D. What is the significance of the Sampo in the story? Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 7.

So, the most similar generated MCQ would be Question 1.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
After a savage seafaring skirmish and eight long days of being 
battered by waves, Väinämöinen— a powerful bard and 
sage as old as the world itself— washed up on the shores 
of distant Pohjola. Unlike his home Kalevala, Pohjola was 
a dark and frozen land, ruled by Louhi, “the gap-tooth 
hag of the North." The cunning witch nursed Väinämöinen 
back to health but demanded a reward for 
returning him home. Not content with mere gold or silver, Louhi wanted what did not yet exist— 
the Sampo. To be forged from “the tips of white-swan
feathers," “the milk of greatest virtue," “a single grain of barley," and 
“the finest wool of lambskins," this artifact was said to be 
an endless font of wealth. But Väinämöinen knew that 
only Seppo Ilmarinen, the Eternal Hammerer who forged 
the sky-dome itself, could craft such an object. So he convinced Louhi to send him 
home and fetch the smith. Though the journey was far from easy, 
the bard finally made it back to Kalevala. But Ilmarinen refused to go to the gloomy 
North— a land of witches and man-eaters. But keeping true to his word, Väinämöinen tricked Ilmarinen 
into climbing a giant tree, before summoning a mighty storm 
to carry the smith all the way to Pohjola. Ilmarinen was well received in the North. Louhi lavished her guest with 
extravagant hospitality and promised him the hand 
of her beautiful daughter— if he could craft what she wished. When she finally asked if Ilmarinen 
was capable of forging the Sampo, the powerful smith declared he could 
indeed accomplish the task. But try as he might to bend 
the forge to his will, its fires only produced other artifacts— beautiful in appearance but 
ill-mannered in nature. An elegant crossbow that 
thirsted for blood and a gleaming plow that ruined cultivated
fields among others. Finally, Ilmarinen summoned the winds 
themselves to work the bellows, and in three days time he 
pulled the Sampo, with its lid of many colors from 
the forge’s flames. On its sides the smith carefully crafted 
a grain mill, a salt mill, and a money mill. Louhi was so delighted with the object’s 
limitless productive power that she ran off to lock her treasure 
inside a mountain. But when Ilmarinen tried to 
claim his prize, the promised maiden refused to marry him,
and the smith had to return home alone. Years passed, and while 
Pohjola prospered, Ilmarinen and Väinämöinen were without 
wives or great wealth. Bitter about this injustice, the bard 
proposed a quest to retrieve the Sampo, and the two sailed north with the 
help of Lemminkäinen— a beautiful young man with a history 
of starting trouble. Upon arrival, Väinämöinen requested half 
the Sampo’s profits as compensation— or they’d take the artifact by force. Outraged at this request, Louhi summoned 
her forces to fight the heroes. But as her army readied for war, 
the bard played his magic harp, Kantele, entrancing all who heard it and sending 
Pohjola into a deep slumber. Unimpeded, the three men took the Sampo 
and quietly made their escape. Lemminkäinen was ecstatic 
at their success, and demanded that Väinämöinen sing 
of their triumph. The bard refused, knowing the dangers 
of celebrating too early. But after three days of traveling, 
Lemminkäinen’s excitement overwhelmed him, and he recklessly broke out in song. His awful singing voice woke 
a nearby crane, whose screeching cries roused 
the Pohjolan horde. The army made chase. As their warship closed in, Väinämöinen 
raised a rock to breach their hull. Undeterred, Louhi transformed 
into a giant eagle, carrying her army on her back as they 
attacked the heroes’ vessel. She managed to grab the Sampo 
in her claw, but just as quickly, it dropped into 
the sea, shattering into pieces and sinking deep beyond her talon’s reach. Buried on the ocean floor, the remnants of this powerful device 
remain in the realm of Ahti, god of water— where they grind salt for the seas 
to this very day.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What does Louhi promise to Ilmarinen for crafting the Sampo?
Options: A. Her daughter’s hand, B. A party with extravagant hospitality, C. A new boat
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: **Knowledge** Options: A. Väinämöinen is a powerful bard and sage from Kalevala., B. Väinämöinen is a cunning witch from Pohjola., C. Väinämöinen is a young man with a history of starting trouble., D. Väinämöinen is a powerful smith from Kalevala. Correct Option: A
Question 2: **Comprehension** Options: A. Väinämöinen washes up on the shores of Kalevala after a seafaring skirmish., B. What are the consequences of Väinämöinen's decision to refuse to sing of their triumph?, D. What is the significance of the Sampo in the story? Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
After a savage seafaring skirmish and eight long days of being 
battered by waves, Väinämöinen— a powerful bard and 
sage as old as the world itself— washed up on the shores 
of distant Pohjola. Unlike his home Kalevala, Pohjola was 
a dark and frozen land, ruled by Louhi, “the gap-tooth 
hag of the North." The cunning witch nursed Väinämöinen 
back to health but demanded a reward for 
returning him home. Not content with mere gold or silver, Louhi wanted what did not yet exist— 
the Sampo. To be forged from “the tips of white-swan
feathers," “the milk of greatest virtue," “a single grain of barley," and 
“the finest wool of lambskins," this artifact was said to be 
an endless font of wealth. But Väinämöinen knew that 
only Seppo Ilmarinen, the Eternal Hammerer who forged 
the sky-dome itself, could craft such an object. So he convinced Louhi to send him 
home and fetch the smith. Though the journey was far from easy, 
the bard finally made it back to Kalevala. But Ilmarinen refused to go to the gloomy 
North— a land of witches and man-eaters. But keeping true to his word, Väinämöinen tricked Ilmarinen 
into climbing a giant tree, before summoning a mighty storm 
to carry the smith all the way to Pohjola. Ilmarinen was well received in the North. Louhi lavished her guest with 
extravagant hospitality and promised him the hand 
of her beautiful daughter— if he could craft what she wished. When she finally asked if Ilmarinen 
was capable of forging the Sampo, the powerful smith declared he could 
indeed accomplish the task. But try as he might to bend 
the forge to his will, its fires only produced other artifacts— beautiful in appearance but 
ill-mannered in nature. An elegant crossbow that 
thirsted for blood and a gleaming plow that ruined cultivated
fields among others. Finally, Ilmarinen summoned the winds 
themselves to work the bellows, and in three days time he 
pulled the Sampo, with its lid of many colors from 
the forge’s flames. On its sides the smith carefully crafted 
a grain mill, a salt mill, and a money mill. Louhi was so delighted with the object’s 
limitless productive power that she ran off to lock her treasure 
inside a mountain. But when Ilmarinen tried to 
claim his prize, the promised maiden refused to marry him,
and the smith had to return home alone. Years passed, and while 
Pohjola prospered, Ilmarinen and Väinämöinen were without 
wives or great wealth. Bitter about this injustice, the bard 
proposed a quest to retrieve the Sampo, and the two sailed north with the 
help of Lemminkäinen— a beautiful young man with a history 
of starting trouble. Upon arrival, Väinämöinen requested half 
the Sampo’s profits as compensation— or they’d take the artifact by force. Outraged at this request, Louhi summoned 
her forces to fight the heroes. But as her army readied for war, 
the bard played his magic harp, Kantele, entrancing all who heard it and sending 
Pohjola into a deep slumber. Unimpeded, the three men took the Sampo 
and quietly made their escape. Lemminkäinen was ecstatic 
at their success, and demanded that Väinämöinen sing 
of their triumph. The bard refused, knowing the dangers 
of celebrating too early. But after three days of traveling, 
Lemminkäinen’s excitement overwhelmed him, and he recklessly broke out in song. His awful singing voice woke 
a nearby crane, whose screeching cries roused 
the Pohjolan horde. The army made chase. As their warship closed in, Väinämöinen 
raised a rock to breach their hull. Undeterred, Louhi transformed 
into a giant eagle, carrying her army on her back as they 
attacked the heroes’ vessel. She managed to grab the Sampo 
in her claw, but just as quickly, it dropped into 
the sea, shattering into pieces and sinking deep beyond her talon’s reach. Buried on the ocean floor, the remnants of this powerful device 
remain in the realm of Ahti, god of water— where they grind salt for the seas 
to this very day.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Where does Louhi hide the Sampo?
Options: A. In the depth of the ocean, B. Under her house, C. In Kalevala, D. Inside a mountain
Correct Option: D

**Transcript**:
After a savage seafaring skirmish and eight long days of being 
battered by waves, Väinämöinen— a powerful bard and 
sage as old as the world itself— washed up on the shores 
of distant Pohjola. Unlike his home Kalevala, Pohjola was 
a dark and frozen land, ruled by Louhi, “the gap-tooth 
hag of the North." The cunning witch nursed Väinämöinen 
back to health but demanded a reward for 
returning him home. Not content with mere gold or silver, Louhi wanted what did not yet exist— 
the Sampo. To be forged from “the tips of white-swan
feathers," “the milk of greatest virtue," “a single grain of barley," and 
“the finest wool of lambskins," this artifact was said to be 
an endless font of wealth. But Väinämöinen knew that 
only Seppo Ilmarinen, the Eternal Hammerer who forged 
the sky-dome itself, could craft such an object. So he convinced Louhi to send him 
home and fetch the smith. Though the journey was far from easy, 
the bard finally made it back to Kalevala. But Ilmarinen refused to go to the gloomy

into climbing a giant tree, before summoning a mighty storm 
to carry the smith all the way to Pohjola. Ilmarinen was well received in the North. Louhi lavished her guest with 
extravagant hospitality and promised him the hand 
of her beautiful daughter— if he could craft what she wished. When she finally asked if Ilmarinen 
was capable of forging the Sampo, the powerful smith declared he could 
indeed accomplish the task. But try as he might to bend 
the forge to his will, its fires only produced other artifacts— beautiful in appearance but 
ill-mannered in nature. An elegant crossbow that 
thirsted for blood and a gleaming plow that ruined cultivated

limitless productive power that she ran off to lock her treasure 
inside a mountain. But when Ilmarinen tried to 
claim his prize, the promised maiden refused to marry him,
and the smith had to return home alone. Years passed, and while

of starting trouble. Upon arrival, Väinämöinen requested half

in her claw, but just as quickly, it dropped into 
the sea, shattering into pieces and sinking deep beyond her talon’s reach. Buried on the ocean floor, the remnants of this powerful device 
remain in the realm of Ahti, god of water— where they grind salt for the seas 
to this very day.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
After a savage seafaring skirmish and eight long days of being 
battered by waves, Väinämöinen— a powerful bard and 
sage as old as the world itself— washed up on the shores 
of distant Pohjola. Unlike his home Kalevala, Pohjola was 
a dark and frozen land, ruled by Louhi, “the gap-tooth 
hag of the North." The cunning witch nursed Väinämöinen 
back to health but demanded a reward for 
returning him home. Not content with mere gold or silver, Louhi wanted what did not yet exist— 
the Sampo. To be forged from “the tips of white-swan
feathers," “the milk of greatest virtue," “a single grain of barley," and 
“the finest wool of lambskins," this artifact was said to be 
an endless font of wealth. But Väinämöinen knew that 
only Seppo Ilmarinen, the Eternal Hammerer who forged 
the sky-dome itself, could craft such an object. So he convinced Louhi to send him 
home and fetch the smith. Though the journey was far from easy, 
the bard finally made it back to Kalevala. But Ilmarinen refused to go to the gloomy 
North— a land of witches and man-eaters. But keeping true to his word, Väinämöinen tricked Ilmarinen 
into climbing a giant tree, before summoning a mighty storm 
to carry the smith all the way to Pohjola. Ilmarinen was well received in the North. Louhi lavished her guest with 
extravagant hospitality and promised him the hand 
of her beautiful daughter— if he could craft what she wished. When she finally asked if Ilmarinen 
was capable of forging the Sampo, the powerful smith declared he could 
indeed accomplish the task. But try as he might to bend 
the forge to his will, its fires only produced other artifacts— beautiful in appearance but 
ill-mannered in nature. An elegant crossbow that 
thirsted for blood and a gleaming plow that ruined cultivated
fields among others. Finally, Ilmarinen summoned the winds 
themselves to work the bellows, and in three days time he 
pulled the Sampo, with its lid of many colors from 
the forge’s flames. On its sides the smith carefully crafted 
a grain mill, a salt mill, and a money mill. Louhi was so delighted with the object’s 
limitless productive power that she ran off to lock her treasure 
inside a mountain. But when Ilmarinen tried to 
claim his prize, the promised maiden refused to marry him,
and the smith had to return home alone. Years passed, and while 
Pohjola prospered, Ilmarinen and Väinämöinen were without 
wives or great wealth. Bitter about this injustice, the bard 
proposed a quest to retrieve the Sampo, and the two sailed north with the 
help of Lemminkäinen— a beautiful young man with a history 
of starting trouble. Upon arrival, Väinämöinen requested half 
the Sampo’s profits as compensation— or they’d take the artifact by force. Outraged at this request, Louhi summoned 
her forces to fight the heroes. But as her army readied for war, 
the bard played his magic harp, Kantele, entrancing all who heard it and sending 
Pohjola into a deep slumber. Unimpeded, the three men took the Sampo 
and quietly made their escape. Lemminkäinen was ecstatic 
at their success, and demanded that Väinämöinen sing 
of their triumph. The bard refused, knowing the dangers 
of celebrating too early. But after three days of traveling, 
Lemminkäinen’s excitement overwhelmed him, and he recklessly broke out in song. His awful singing voice woke 
a nearby crane, whose screeching cries roused 
the Pohjolan horde. The army made chase. As their warship closed in, Väinämöinen 
raised a rock to breach their hull. Undeterred, Louhi transformed 
into a giant eagle, carrying her army on her back as they 
attacked the heroes’ vessel. She managed to grab the Sampo 
in her claw, but just as quickly, it dropped into 
the sea, shattering into pieces and sinking deep beyond her talon’s reach. Buried on the ocean floor, the remnants of this powerful device 
remain in the realm of Ahti, god of water— where they grind salt for the seas 
to this very day.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: While trying to retrieve the Sampo, Louhi transforms into
Options: A. a dragon, B. a giant eagle, C. a monstrous seal
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:

What would happen if Väinämöinen and Lemminkäinen were to return to the North and try to retrieve the Sampo again?, D. How would the story change if Louhi were a kind and benevolent character instead of a cunning witch? Correct Option: A

Why or why not?, C. Do you think the Sampo is an important plot device in the story? Why or why not?, D. Is Lemminkäinen a well-developed character in the story? Why or why not? Correct Option: A
Question 7: **Knowledge** Options: A. Seppo Ilmarinen is the smith who forges the Sampo., B. Louhi is the one who demands the Sampo from Väinämöinen., C. Lemminkäinen is the one who helps Väinämöinen in his quest to retrieve the Sampo., D. Väinämöinen is the one who refuses to go to the North to craft the Sampo. Correct Option: A
Question 8: **Comprehension** Options: A. Väinämöinen and Lemminkäinen sail north with the help of the wind., B. Väinämöinen and Lemminkäinen sail north with the help of a magical boat., C. Väinämöinen and Lemminkäinen sail north with the help of a beautiful maiden., D. Väinämöinen and Lemminkäinen sail north with the help of Lemminkäinen's magical harp. Correct Option: A
Question 9: **Application** Options: A. If you were Väinämöinen, how would you react to Louhi's demand for the Sampo?, B. What would you do if you were Louhi and Väinämöinen refused to give you the Sampo?, C. If you were Lemminkäinen, how would you feel if Väinämöinen refused to sing of their triumph?, D. What would you do if you were Seppo Ilmarinen and Louhi asked you to craft the Sampo? Correct Option: A
Question 10: **Analysis** Options: A. What are the main themes of the story?, B. How does the story relate to the concept of good vs. evil?, C. What are the consequences of Väinämöinen's decision to refuse to sing of their triumph?, D. What is the significance of the Sampo in the story? Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
When the Hoover Dam was 
completed in 1936, it created a huge source of 
hydroelectric power and zapped a sleepy desert town to life: 
Las Vegas, Nevada. With the power supply from the dam, Las Vegas soon exploded 
with vibrant displays. The source of these dazzling lights was 
electrified neon gas. There are two tricky obstacles 
to making lighted signs out of this naturally clear, 
odorless gas: capturing it and making it glow. French inventor Georges Claude came up 
with techniques to do both. In 1902, he developed a way of liquefying and 
separating specific gases from the air, producing neon on an industrial 
scale for the first time. By 1910, he had come up with a way 
to trap the gas in a glass tube with a special electrode at either end, 
and neon lighting was born. In workshops like Claude's, artisans known as tube-benders 
made neon signs by hand. The tube-benders heated small sections 
of a long, hollow glass tube and quickly bent them into shape. After the glass cooled, they attached 
electrodes to each end and removed the air with a vacuum pump. Then, they passed a high voltage 
current through the tube to remove any impurities on the 
inside of the glass. Finally, they pumped the neon gas in 
and sealed off the electrodes. When a neon sign is turned on, the electric current causes some of 
the neon atoms' electrons to accelerate and break free of their orbits, leaving 
behind positively charged ions. As these free electrons rush from 
one electrode to the other, they collide with more neon atoms, 
causing them to ionize as well. When these excited electrons fall back 
to their normal energy levels, their excess energy is carried away 
by photons, or particles of light. All this happens in an instant, and the glow from the photons is what 
we see when we switch on a neon sign. Though it's common to call any 
gas-filled sign a "neon" sign, there are actually 5 different 
gases used in production. Each gas emits photons of a different 
wavelength when electrified, which correspond to different 
colors of light. Neon gives off an orange-red glow, argon 
glows a pale lavender, helium a dusty pink, krypton a silver-
white, and xenon a light purple. These 5 gases can be combined 
with color-coated tubing to create an electrified rainbow of 
text and images. Business owners soon realized how 
effective these colorful beacons were for attracting customers. And unlike a light bulb, a neon sign has 
no incandescent filaments to burn out, and can shine continuously for 40 years 
before the gas depletes. By the 1930s, neon signs were lighting 
up storefronts all over the world. Because of the glass tubes' 
fragile nature, it usually wasn't feasible to ship 
them over long distances. Instead, most neon signs were created by 
local neon shops and then installed nearby. Signs with humor, personality, and 
intricate designs proliferated, no two exactly alike. But by the end of World War II, plastics had become widely 
available and inexpensive, and plastic signs supplanted neon 
as messengers of modernity. Many towns removed neon signs they 
viewed as old-fashioned. Today, neon sign production is only 
a fraction of what it was at its peak, but the craft of tube bending lives 
on relatively unchanged. New creations hand-crafted 
by local artisans join survivors from the heyday of neon, hiding in plain sight in city streets 
around the world.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Neon lighting was first commercially produced in which country?
Options: A. Italy, B. United States, C. France, D. England
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: When was the Hoover Dam completed? Options: A. 1902, B. 1910, C. 1936, D. 1945 Correct Option: C
Question 2: What source of power did the Hoover Dam provide to Las Vegas? Options: A. Solar power, B. Hydroelectric power, C. Wind power, D. Geothermal power Correct Option: B
Question 3: Who invented techniques to capture and make neon gas glow? Options: A. Thomas Edison, B. Nikola Tesla, C. Georges Claude, D. Albert Einstein Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the process of heating small sections of a glass tube and bending them into shape called? Options: A. Vacuum pumping, B. Electrode attachment, C. Tube-bending, D. Glass cooling Correct Option: C
Question 5: What happens when a neon sign is turned on? Options: A. The gas inside the tube expands, B. The electrons in the neon atoms break free and accelerate, C. The glass tube shatters, D. The sign turns off Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the main difference between a neon sign and a light bulb? Options: A. Neon signs use incandescent filaments, while light bulbs do not, B. Neon signs have no incandescent filaments, while light bulbs do, C. Neon signs use a different type of gas, D. Neon signs are more expensive than light bulbs Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the average lifespan of a neon sign before the gas depletes? Options: A. 10 years, B. 20 years, C. 30 years, D. 40 years Correct Option: D
Question 8: Why were neon signs often created by local shops and installed nearby? Options: A. Because they were too expensive to ship, B. Because they were too fragile to handle, C. Because they were too heavy to transport, D. Because they were too complex to ship over long distances Correct Option: D
Question 9: What happened to neon sign production after World War II? Options: A. It increased dramatically, B. It remained the same, C. It decreased significantly, D. It was replaced by a new technology Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the current state of neon sign production compared to its peak? Options: A. It is now more popular than ever, B. It is still widely used, C. It is a fraction of what it was at its peak, D. It has been completely replaced by a new technology Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 3: Who invented techniques to capture and make neon gas glow? Options: A. Thomas Edison, B. Nikola Tesla, C. Georges Claude, D. Albert Einstein Correct Option: C**

This question is similar to the ground truth MCQ because it:

1. Deals with the origin of neon lighting.
2. Mentions a specific country/person associated with the invention (Georges Claude is French).
3. Has a similar intent to the ground truth MCQ, which asks about the country where neon lighting was first commercially produced.

While the generated MCQ does not directly ask about the country of origin, it provides a strong hint about the connection between Georges Claude and neon lighting, which is closely related to the ground truth MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: **3**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
When the Hoover Dam was 
completed in 1936, it created a huge source of 
hydroelectric power and zapped a sleepy desert town to life: 
Las Vegas, Nevada. With the power supply from the dam, Las Vegas soon exploded 
with vibrant displays. The source of these dazzling lights was 
electrified neon gas. There are two tricky obstacles 
to making lighted signs out of this naturally clear, 
odorless gas: capturing it and making it glow. French inventor Georges Claude came up 
with techniques to do both. In 1902, he developed a way of liquefying and 
separating specific gases from the air, producing neon on an industrial 
scale for the first time. By 1910, he had come up with a way 
to trap the gas in a glass tube with a special electrode at either end, 
and neon lighting was born. In workshops like Claude's, artisans known as tube-benders 
made neon signs by hand. The tube-benders heated small sections 
of a long, hollow glass tube and quickly bent them into shape. After the glass cooled, they attached 
electrodes to each end and removed the air with a vacuum pump. Then, they passed a high voltage 
current through the tube to remove any impurities on the 
inside of the glass. Finally, they pumped the neon gas in 
and sealed off the electrodes. When a neon sign is turned on, the electric current causes some of 
the neon atoms' electrons to accelerate and break free of their orbits, leaving 
behind positively charged ions. As these free electrons rush from 
one electrode to the other, they collide with more neon atoms, 
causing them to ionize as well. When these excited electrons fall back 
to their normal energy levels, their excess energy is carried away 
by photons, or particles of light. All this happens in an instant, and the glow from the photons is what 
we see when we switch on a neon sign. Though it's common to call any 
gas-filled sign a "neon" sign, there are actually 5 different 
gases used in production. Each gas emits photons of a different 
wavelength when electrified, which correspond to different 
colors of light. Neon gives off an orange-red glow, argon 
glows a pale lavender, helium a dusty pink, krypton a silver-
white, and xenon a light purple. These 5 gases can be combined 
with color-coated tubing to create an electrified rainbow of 
text and images. Business owners soon realized how 
effective these colorful beacons were for attracting customers. And unlike a light bulb, a neon sign has 
no incandescent filaments to burn out, and can shine continuously for 40 years 
before the gas depletes. By the 1930s, neon signs were lighting 
up storefronts all over the world. Because of the glass tubes' 
fragile nature, it usually wasn't feasible to ship 
them over long distances. Instead, most neon signs were created by 
local neon shops and then installed nearby. Signs with humor, personality, and 
intricate designs proliferated, no two exactly alike. But by the end of World War II, plastics had become widely 
available and inexpensive, and plastic signs supplanted neon 
as messengers of modernity. Many towns removed neon signs they 
viewed as old-fashioned. Today, neon sign production is only 
a fraction of what it was at its peak, but the craft of tube bending lives 
on relatively unchanged. New creations hand-crafted 
by local artisans join survivors from the heyday of neon, hiding in plain sight in city streets 
around the world.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Excess energy from excited electrons are carried away by particles of light called?
Options: A. photons, B. molecules, C. gamma rays, D. x-rays
Correct Option: A

Question 5: What happens when a neon sign is turned on? Options: A. The gas inside the tube expands, B. The electrons in the neon atoms break free and accelerate, C. The glass tube shatters, D. The sign turns off Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the main difference between a neon sign and a light bulb? Options: A. Neon signs use incandescent filaments, while light bulbs do not, B. Neon signs have no incandescent filaments, while light bulbs do, C. Neon signs use a different type of gas, D. Neon signs are more expensive than light bulbs Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
When the Hoover Dam was 
completed in 1936, it created a huge source of 
hydroelectric power and zapped a sleepy desert town to life: 
Las Vegas, Nevada. With the power supply from the dam, Las Vegas soon exploded 
with vibrant displays. The source of these dazzling lights was 
electrified neon gas. There are two tricky obstacles 
to making lighted signs out of this naturally clear, 
odorless gas: capturing it and making it glow. French inventor Georges Claude came up 
with techniques to do both. In 1902, he developed a way of liquefying and 
separating specific gases from the air, producing neon on an industrial 
scale for the first time. By 1910, he had come up with a way 
to trap the gas in a glass tube with a special electrode at either end, 
and neon lighting was born. In workshops like Claude's, artisans known as tube-benders 
made neon signs by hand. The tube-benders heated small sections 
of a long, hollow glass tube and quickly bent them into shape. After the glass cooled, they attached 
electrodes to each end and removed the air with a vacuum pump. Then, they passed a high voltage 
current through the tube to remove any impurities on the 
inside of the glass. Finally, they pumped the neon gas in 
and sealed off the electrodes. When a neon sign is turned on, the electric current causes some of 
the neon atoms' electrons to accelerate and break free of their orbits, leaving 
behind positively charged ions. As these free electrons rush from 
one electrode to the other, they collide with more neon atoms, 
causing them to ionize as well. When these excited electrons fall back 
to their normal energy levels, their excess energy is carried away 
by photons, or particles of light. All this happens in an instant, and the glow from the photons is what 
we see when we switch on a neon sign. Though it's common to call any 
gas-filled sign a "neon" sign, there are actually 5 different 
gases used in production. Each gas emits photons of a different 
wavelength when electrified, which correspond to different 
colors of light. Neon gives off an orange-red glow, argon 
glows a pale lavender, helium a dusty pink, krypton a silver-
white, and xenon a light purple. These 5 gases can be combined 
with color-coated tubing to create an electrified rainbow of 
text and images. Business owners soon realized how 
effective these colorful beacons were for attracting customers. And unlike a light bulb, a neon sign has 
no incandescent filaments to burn out, and can shine continuously for 40 years 
before the gas depletes. By the 1930s, neon signs were lighting 
up storefronts all over the world. Because of the glass tubes' 
fragile nature, it usually wasn't feasible to ship 
them over long distances. Instead, most neon signs were created by 
local neon shops and then installed nearby. Signs with humor, personality, and 
intricate designs proliferated, no two exactly alike. But by the end of World War II, plastics had become widely 
available and inexpensive, and plastic signs supplanted neon 
as messengers of modernity. Many towns removed neon signs they 
viewed as old-fashioned. Today, neon sign production is only 
a fraction of what it was at its peak, but the craft of tube bending lives 
on relatively unchanged. New creations hand-crafted 
by local artisans join survivors from the heyday of neon, hiding in plain sight in city streets 
around the world.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Neon signs can shine for up to how many years before the gas depletes?
Options: A. 5, B. 25, C. 40, D. 50
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: When was the Hoover Dam completed? Options: A. 1902, B. 1910, C. 1936, D. 1945 Correct Option: C
Question 2: What source of power did the Hoover Dam provide to Las Vegas? Options: A. Solar power, B. Hydroelectric power, C. Wind power, D. Geothermal power Correct Option: B
Question 3: Who invented techniques to capture and make neon gas glow? Options: A. Thomas Edison, B. Nikola Tesla, C. Georges Claude, D. Albert Einstein Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the process of heating small sections of a glass tube and bending them into shape called? Options: A. Vacuum pumping, B. Electrode attachment, C. Tube-bending, D. Glass cooling Correct Option: C
Question 5: What happens when a neon sign is turned on? Options: A. The gas inside the tube expands, B. The electrons in the neon atoms break free and accelerate, C. The glass tube shatters, D. The sign turns off Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the main difference between a neon sign and a light bulb? Options: A. Neon signs use incandescent filaments, while light bulbs do not, B. Neon signs have no incandescent filaments, while light bulbs do, C. Neon signs use a different type of gas, D. Neon signs are more expensive than light bulbs Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the average lifespan of a neon sign before the gas depletes? Options: A. 10 years, B. 20 years, C. 30 years, D. 40 years Correct Option: D
Question 8: Why were neon signs often created by local shops and installed nearby? Options: A. Because they were too expensive to ship, B. Because they were too fragile to handle, C. Because they were too heavy to transport, D. Because they were too complex to ship over long distances Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
When the Hoover Dam was 
completed in 1936, it created a huge source of 
hydroelectric power and zapped a sleepy desert town to life: 
Las Vegas, Nevada. With the power supply from the dam, Las Vegas soon exploded 
with vibrant displays. The source of these dazzling lights was 
electrified neon gas. There are two tricky obstacles 
to making lighted signs out of this naturally clear, 
odorless gas: capturing it and making it glow. French inventor Georges Claude came up 
with techniques to do both. In 1902, he developed a way of liquefying and 
separating specific gases from the air, producing neon on an industrial 
scale for the first time. By 1910, he had come up with a way 
to trap the gas in a glass tube with a special electrode at either end, 
and neon lighting was born. In workshops like Claude's, artisans known as tube-benders 
made neon signs by hand. The tube-benders heated small sections 
of a long, hollow glass tube and quickly bent them into shape. After the glass cooled, they attached 
electrodes to each end and removed the air with a vacuum pump. Then, they passed a high voltage 
current through the tube to remove any impurities on the 
inside of the glass. Finally, they pumped the neon gas in 
and sealed off the electrodes. When a neon sign is turned on, the electric current causes some of 
the neon atoms' electrons to accelerate and break free of their orbits, leaving 
behind positively charged ions. As these free electrons rush from 
one electrode to the other, they collide with more neon atoms, 
causing them to ionize as well. When these excited electrons fall back 
to their normal energy levels, their excess energy is carried away 
by photons, or particles of light. All this happens in an instant, and the glow from the photons is what 
we see when we switch on a neon sign. Though it's common to call any 
gas-filled sign a "neon" sign, there are actually 5 different 
gases used in production. Each gas emits photons of a different 
wavelength when electrified, which correspond to different 
colors of light. Neon gives off an orange-red glow, argon 
glows a pale lavender, helium a dusty pink, krypton a silver-
white, and xenon a light purple. These 5 gases can be combined 
with color-coated tubing to create an electrified rainbow of 
text and images. Business owners soon realized how 
effective these colorful beacons were for attracting customers. And unlike a light bulb, a neon sign has 
no incandescent filaments to burn out, and can shine continuously for 40 years 
before the gas depletes. By the 1930s, neon signs were lighting 
up storefronts all over the world. Because of the glass tubes' 
fragile nature, it usually wasn't feasible to ship 
them over long distances. Instead, most neon signs were created by 
local neon shops and then installed nearby. Signs with humor, personality, and 
intricate designs proliferated, no two exactly alike. But by the end of World War II, plastics had become widely 
available and inexpensive, and plastic signs supplanted neon 
as messengers of modernity. Many towns removed neon signs they 
viewed as old-fashioned. Today, neon sign production is only 
a fraction of what it was at its peak, but the craft of tube bending lives 
on relatively unchanged. New creations hand-crafted 
by local artisans join survivors from the heyday of neon, hiding in plain sight in city streets 
around the world.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why did neon signs become less popular?
Options: A. Their gas leaked poison, B. Glass became outlawed in the 1950s, C. Cheap plastic signs replaced them, D. People got bored of seeing gorgeous, handmade light sculptures
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: When was the Hoover Dam completed? Options: A. 1902, B. 1910, C. 1936, D. 1945 Correct Option: C
Question 2: What source of power did the Hoover Dam provide to Las Vegas? Options: A. Solar power, B. Hydroelectric power, C. Wind power, D. Geothermal power Correct Option: B
Question 3: Who invented techniques to capture and make neon gas glow? Options: A. Thomas Edison, B. Nikola Tesla, C. Georges Claude, D. Albert Einstein Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the process of heating small sections of a glass tube and bending them into shape called? Options: A. Vacuum pumping, B. Electrode attachment, C. Tube-bending, D. Glass cooling Correct Option: C
Question 5: What happens when a neon sign is turned on? Options: A. The gas inside the tube expands, B. The electrons in the neon atoms break free and accelerate, C. The glass tube shatters, D. The sign turns off Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the main difference between a neon sign and a light bulb? Options: A. Neon signs use incandescent filaments, while light bulbs do not, B. Neon signs have no incandescent filaments, while light bulbs do, C. Neon signs use a different type of gas, D. Neon signs are more expensive than light bulbs Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the average lifespan of a neon sign before the gas depletes? Options: A. 10 years, B. 20 years, C. 30 years, D. 40 years Correct Option: D
Question 8: Why were neon signs often created by local shops and installed nearby? Options: A. Because they were too expensive to ship, B. Because they were too fragile to handle, C. Because they were too heavy to transport, D. Because they were too complex to ship over long distances Correct Option: D

Question 10: What is the current state of neon sign production compared to its peak? Options: A. It is now more popular than ever, B. It is still widely used, C. It is a fraction of what it was at its peak, D. It has been completely replaced by a new technology Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 9: What happened to neon sign production after World War II? Options: A. It increased dramatically, B. It remained the same, C. It decreased significantly, D. It was replaced by a new technology Correct Option: C.

However, an even more similar generated MCQ is Question 10, but with a slight modification to match the ground truth MCQ more closely, the correct similar question is indeed Question 10's information but found in Question 9.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
One of the top chefs from Pasta Palace has been kidnapped by operatives 
from Burger Bazaar hoping to learn the location of their 
secret sauce recipe. Little do they know that a third party— Sausage Saloon— has sent you to take advantage 
of the situation. As their top spy, your skills range from 
infiltration and subterfuge, to safecracking and reading faces 
for signs of deception. You’ve tracked the captors to where 
they’re holding the chef prisoner. From your hiding spot, you can see him 
on the other side of the glass, while in front of you an interrogator 
wearing headphones speaks into a microphone. “We already know the recipe is on the 
13th floor of the bank vault, in a safe deposit box numbered between 
13 and 1300. Now tell us… Is the number less than 500?” You can’t hear the chef’s answer, 
but you can see that he’s lying. The interrogator, however, falls for it. He follows up by asking, 
“Is it a perfect square?” Again you can’t hear the answer 
but can tell the chef is lying, while the interrogator takes 
him at his word. He then asks, “Is it a perfect cube?” This time the chef answers truthfully. The interrogator thinks 
for a minute and says, “Good. Now if you just tell me whether 
or not the number’s second digit is a one, we’ll be done here.” But as the chef starts to answer, the interrogator stands up, 
blocking your view. Within moments he rushes out of the room, announcing that he’s got the answer and 
is sending agents to retrieve the recipe. You know that the Burger Bazaar people 
have the wrong box number. But can you figure out the right one 
and retrieve the recipe yourself? Pause the video to figure it 
out for yourself. Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 The key here is to work backwards. We don’t know what the chef answers 
to the final question or whether he answers truthfully. But we do know that by the time 
the interrogator asks it, he’s narrowed the options 
down to two numbers– one where the second digit is 1, 
and one where it isn’t. Our goal, then, is to find answers to the 
previous questions that lead to just two possibilities. Of the three constraints offered, the one that narrows our options the most 
is if the number is a perfect cube. That leaves us with only eight answers 
between 13 and 1300. So let’s assume the answer to the 
third question was a truthful YES. Now, let’s look at the second question. If the chef answered YES to the number 
being a perfect square, it would narrow the interrogator’s options
to just 64 and 729– the only numbers in our range that are 
both a square and a cube. But neither of these has a 1 
as the second digit. So the given answer to the second question
must’ve been NO. And that also means we can eliminate these
two squares from the interrogator's list, leaving only six numbers. Now for the first question, 
which allows us to divide this list. If the chef answered YES to the number 
being less than 500, we’d have four options, which is too many. But a NO leaves us with two numbers 
greater than 500, one of which does have 
a 1 as its second digit. We don’t know which of these numbers 
the interrogator thinks is correct. But that doesn’t matter– remember, his conclusion 
was based on lies. You, on the other hand, are now in a 
position to reconstruct the truth. First, the chef said the number was 
greater than 500 but lied, meaning it’s actually less than 500. Second, the chef said it wasn’t a 
perfect square but lied again, meaning the number is indeed a square. And finally, he truthfully confirmed 
that it was also a cube. And as we’ve already seen, the only number under 500 that’s 
both a square and a cube is 64. You find the secret recipe and are gone 
before anyone’s the wiser. Corporate espionage is not an easy game— but sometimes, that’s just 
how the sausage is made.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why don’t you know what actual answers the chef gives?
Options: A. You can’t see him, B. You can’t hear him, C. He’s prevented from answering
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the main goal of the top spy sent by Sausage Saloon to Pasta Palace? Options: A. To infiltrate Burger Bazaar and gather information, B. To steal the secret recipe from Burger Bazaar, C. To rescue the kidnapped chef from Pasta Palace, D. To learn the location of Burger Bazaar's secret sauce recipe Correct Option: D
Question 2: What information does the interrogator initially gather from the chef? Options: A. The number is between 13 and 1300, B. The number is less than 500, C. The number is a perfect square, D. The number is a perfect cube Correct Option: A
Question 3: What is the outcome if the chef answers truthfully to the third question ("Is it a perfect cube?")? Options: A. The interrogator narrows the options to two numbers, B. The interrogator eliminates all options, C. The chef is freed from captivity, D. The interrogator leaves the room Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the significance of the chef's answer to the second question ("Is it a perfect square?")? Options: A. It eliminates two numbers from the options, B. It confirms the number is between 13 and 1300, C. It reveals the number's second digit, D. It indicates the number is greater than 500 Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the result of the chef's lie about the number being less than 500? Options: A. The interrogator narrows the options to two numbers, B. The interrogator eliminates all options greater than 500, C. The chef is freed from captivity, D. The interrogator leaves the room Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the only number under 500 that is both a square and a cube? Options: A. 729, B. 1000, C. 1300, D. 64 Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is the main difference between the interrogator's conclusion and the spy's conclusion? Options: A. The interrogator's conclusion is based on truth, while the spy's conclusion is based on lies, B. The interrogator's conclusion is based on lies, while the spy's conclusion is based on truth, C. The interrogator's conclusion is more accurate than the spy's conclusion, D. The interrogator's conclusion is less accurate than the spy's conclusion Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the significance of the interrogator standing up and leaving the room? Options: A. It indicates the interrogator is confused, B. It indicates the interrogator has eliminated all options, C. It indicates the interrogator has found the correct answer, D. It indicates the interrogator is giving up Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the ultimate goal of the spy sent by Sausage Saloon? Options: A. To learn the location of Burger Bazaar's secret sauce recipe, B. To infiltrate Burger Bazaar and gather information, C. To rescue the kidnapped chef from Pasta Palace, D. To steal the secret recipe from Burger Bazaar Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the final outcome of the story? Options: A. The spy fails to retrieve the secret recipe, B. The story ends with a cliffhanger, C. The spy retrieves the secret recipe and escapes, D. The spy is caught by Burger Bazaar Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content, options, and overall intent. However, I can try to find the one that is closest in terms of relevance to the context.

The ground truth MCQ asks why the spy doesn't know what actual answers the chef gives, and the correct option is that the spy can't hear the chef. 

While none of the generated MCQs ask this exact question, Question 2 is the closest in terms of context, as it discusses the information the interrogator gathers from the chef. However, it doesn't address why the spy can't know the chef's answers.

If I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ, I would say that none of them match the ground truth MCQ. However, if you'd like me to pick one that is somewhat related to the context, I would say Question 2 is the closest, but it's still not a good match.

Index: 2 (with the caveat that it's not a good match)

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 3

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the main goal of the top spy sent by Sausage Saloon to Pasta Palace? Options: A. To infiltrate Burger Bazaar and gather information, B. To steal the secret recipe from Burger Bazaar, C. To rescue the kidnapped chef from Pasta Palace, D. To learn the location of Burger Bazaar's secret sauce recipe Correct Option: D
Question 2: What information does the interrogator initially gather from the chef? Options: A. The number is between 13 and 1300, B. The number is less than 500, C. The number is a perfect square, D. The number is a perfect cube Correct Option: A
Question 3: What is the outcome if the chef answers truthfully to the third question ("Is it a perfect cube?")? Options: A. The interrogator narrows the options to two numbers, B. The interrogator eliminates all options, C. The chef is freed from captivity, D. The interrogator leaves the room Correct Option: A

It confirms the number is between 13 and 1300, C. It reveals the number's second digit, D. It indicates the number is greater than 500 Correct Option: A

The interrogator's conclusion is based on truth, while the spy's conclusion is based on lies, B. The interrogator's conclusion is based on lies, while the spy's conclusion is based on truth, C. The interrogator's conclusion is more accurate than the spy's conclusion, D. The interrogator's conclusion is less accurate than the spy's conclusion Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
One of the top chefs from Pasta Palace has been kidnapped by operatives 
from Burger Bazaar hoping to learn the location of their 
secret sauce recipe. Little do they know that a third party— Sausage Saloon— has sent you to take advantage 
of the situation. As their top spy, your skills range from 
infiltration and subterfuge, to safecracking and reading faces 
for signs of deception. You’ve tracked the captors to where 
they’re holding the chef prisoner. From your hiding spot, you can see him 
on the other side of the glass, while in front of you an interrogator 
wearing headphones speaks into a microphone. “We already know the recipe is on the 
13th floor of the bank vault, in a safe deposit box numbered between 
13 and 1300. Now tell us… Is the number less than 500?” You can’t hear the chef’s answer, 
but you can see that he’s lying. The interrogator, however, falls for it. He follows up by asking, 
“Is it a perfect square?” Again you can’t hear the answer 
but can tell the chef is lying, while the interrogator takes 
him at his word. He then asks, “Is it a perfect cube?” This time the chef answers truthfully. The interrogator thinks 
for a minute and says, “Good. Now if you just tell me whether 
or not the number’s second digit is a one, we’ll be done here.” But as the chef starts to answer, the interrogator stands up, 
blocking your view. Within moments he rushes out of the room, announcing that he’s got the answer and 
is sending agents to retrieve the recipe. You know that the Burger Bazaar people 
have the wrong box number. But can you figure out the right one 
and retrieve the recipe yourself? Pause the video to figure it 
out for yourself. Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 The key here is to work backwards. We don’t know what the chef answers 
to the final question or whether he answers truthfully. But we do know that by the time 
the interrogator asks it, he’s narrowed the options 
down to two numbers– one where the second digit is 1, 
and one where it isn’t. Our goal, then, is to find answers to the 
previous questions that lead to just two possibilities. Of the three constraints offered, the one that narrows our options the most 
is if the number is a perfect cube. That leaves us with only eight answers 
between 13 and 1300. So let’s assume the answer to the 
third question was a truthful YES. Now, let’s look at the second question. If the chef answered YES to the number 
being a perfect square, it would narrow the interrogator’s options
to just 64 and 729– the only numbers in our range that are 
both a square and a cube. But neither of these has a 1 
as the second digit. So the given answer to the second question
must’ve been NO. And that also means we can eliminate these
two squares from the interrogator's list, leaving only six numbers. Now for the first question, 
which allows us to divide this list. If the chef answered YES to the number 
being less than 500, we’d have four options, which is too many. But a NO leaves us with two numbers 
greater than 500, one of which does have 
a 1 as its second digit. We don’t know which of these numbers 
the interrogator thinks is correct. But that doesn’t matter– remember, his conclusion 
was based on lies. You, on the other hand, are now in a 
position to reconstruct the truth. First, the chef said the number was 
greater than 500 but lied, meaning it’s actually less than 500. Second, the chef said it wasn’t a 
perfect square but lied again, meaning the number is indeed a square. And finally, he truthfully confirmed 
that it was also a cube. And as we’ve already seen, the only number under 500 that’s 
both a square and a cube is 64. You find the secret recipe and are gone 
before anyone’s the wiser. Corporate espionage is not an easy game— but sometimes, that’s just 
how the sausage is made.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What number box does the interrogator think the recipe is in?
Options: A. 64, B. 512, C. We don’t know
Correct Option: C

Generated MCQ 8: What is the significance of the interrogator standing up and leaving the room?

However, if I had to choose a generated MCQ that is more similar in terms of question content, I would say that there is no exact match, but Generated MCQ 6 is the closest in terms of providing a specific number as an answer.

Generated MCQ 6: What is the only number under 500 that is both a square and a cube?
Options: A. 729, B. 1000, C. 1300, D. 64

This question provides a specific number as an answer, which is similar to the ground truth MCQ. However, the question intent is different, as the ground truth MCQ asks about the interrogator's conclusion, while Generated MCQ 6 asks about a specific property of the number.

In summary, while there is no exact match, I would say that Generated MCQ 8 is the closest in terms of question intent, and Generated MCQ 6 is the closest in terms of question content.

**Transcript**:
One of the top chefs from Pasta Palace has been kidnapped by operatives 
from Burger Bazaar hoping to learn the location of their 
secret sauce recipe. Little do they know that a third party— Sausage Saloon— has sent you to take advantage 
of the situation. As their top spy, your skills range from 
infiltration and subterfuge, to safecracking and reading faces 
for signs of deception. You’ve tracked the captors to where 
they’re holding the chef prisoner. From your hiding spot, you can see him 
on the other side of the glass, while in front of you an interrogator 
wearing headphones speaks into a microphone. “We already know the recipe is on the 
13th floor of the bank vault, in a safe deposit box numbered between 
13 and 1300. Now tell us… Is the number less than 500?” You can’t hear the chef’s answer, 
but you can see that he’s lying. The interrogator, however, falls for it. He follows up by asking, 
“Is it a perfect square?” Again you can’t hear the answer 
but can tell the chef is lying, while the interrogator takes 
him at his word. He then asks, “Is it a perfect cube?” This time the chef answers truthfully. The interrogator thinks 
for a minute and says, “Good. Now if you just tell me whether 
or not the number’s second digit is a one, we’ll be done here.” But as the chef starts to answer, the interrogator stands up, 
blocking your view. Within moments he rushes out of the room, announcing that he’s got the answer and 
is sending agents to retrieve the recipe. You know that the Burger Bazaar people 
have the wrong box number. But can you figure out the right one 
and retrieve the recipe yourself? Pause the video to figure it 
out for yourself. Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 The key here is to work backwards. We don’t know what the chef answers 
to the final question or whether he answers truthfully. But we do know that by the time 
the interrogator asks it, he’s narrowed the options 
down to two numbers– one where the second digit is 1, 
and one where it isn’t. Our goal, then, is to find answers to the 
previous questions that lead to just two possibilities. Of the three constraints offered, the one that narrows our options the most 
is if the number is a perfect cube. That leaves us with only eight answers 
between 13 and 1300. So let’s assume the answer to the 
third question was a truthful YES. Now, let’s look at the second question. If the chef answered YES to the number 
being a perfect square, it would narrow the interrogator’s options
to just 64 and 729– the only numbers in our range that are 
both a square and a cube. But neither of these has a 1 
as the second digit. So the given answer to the second question
must’ve been NO. And that also means we can eliminate these
two squares from the interrogator's list, leaving only six numbers. Now for the first question, 
which allows us to divide this list. If the chef answered YES to the number 
being less than 500, we’d have four options, which is too many. But a NO leaves us with two numbers 
greater than 500, one of which does have 
a 1 as its second digit. We don’t know which of these numbers 
the interrogator thinks is correct. But that doesn’t matter– remember, his conclusion 
was based on lies. You, on the other hand, are now in a 
position to reconstruct the truth. First, the chef said the number was 
greater than 500 but lied, meaning it’s actually less than 500. Second, the chef said it wasn’t a 
perfect square but lied again, meaning the number is indeed a square. And finally, he truthfully confirmed 
that it was also a cube. And as we’ve already seen, the only number under 500 that’s

how the sausage is made.
